topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset module¶

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.print_words_that_contain_elem(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.common.Dataset, elem: str)[source]¶
Prints a table with the following info:

  • Word that contains the given element.

  • Number of occurrences of the word in the whole dataset

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset.

  • elem – Elem contained in the printed words. Will be used to create a regular expression, containing only that elem.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.print_docs_that_contain_word(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, word: str, num_chars_preview=70)[source]¶
Prints a table with the following properties of all documents in the dataset that contain the given word:

  • Category name

  • Index inside the document list of that category (in the dataset.files_dic)

  • Number of words of that document

  • Number of occurrences of the word in that document

  • Document name in the dataset

  • Preview of the document content

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset.

  • word – Word contained in the printed documents.

  • num_chars_preview – Number of characters to show in the preview column.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.print_empty_docs(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset)[source]¶

Prints the empty documents in the given dataset.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.get_docs_that_contain_any_of_the_words(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, words: Union[str, Set[str]]) → List[Tuple[str, int]][source]¶

Returns a list of tuples with the category and index of the docs containing any of the given words. Words can be a simple string, representing only one word.

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset.

  • words – It can be a string representing a single word or a set of strings representing one or more words.

Returns

List of tuples, where tuple[0] contains the category of the doc with the any of the given words and tuple[1] contains the index inside the category of the doc with any of the given words.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.remove_docs_that_contain_any_of_the_given_words(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, words: Union[str, Set[str]])[source]¶

Removes from the given dataset the documents that contain one or more of the given words. Words can be a simple string, representing only one word.

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset where docs will be removed. The dataset is modified.

  • words – It can be a string representing a single word or a set of strings representing one or more words.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.remove_docs_that_contain_any_of_the_words_in_file(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, file_path: str = None)[source]¶

Removes from the given dataset the documents that contain one or more of the words in the specified file.

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset where docs will be removed. The dataset is modified.

  • file_path – Path to the file. The file must contain a word in each line.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.remove_trash_docs_specified_in_file(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, file_path: str = None, file_sep=' ')[source]¶

Removes from the given dataset the documents specified in a file.

Parameters

  • dataset – Dataset where docs will be removed. The dataset is modified.

  • file_path – Path to the file where the trash docs are specified. The file must contain in each line the category and then the name of the file to be removed. Category and name must be separated by the element specified in ‘file_sep’ parameter.

  • file_sep – Separator of the category and the name in the file.

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.remove_empty_docs(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset) → int[source]¶

Removes the empty documents of the given dataset.

Parameters

dataset – Dataset where empty docs will be removed. The dataset is modified.

Returns

The number of documents removed (is the same as the number of empty documents in the dataset).

topics_and_summary.preprocessing.dataset.preprocess_dataset(dataset: topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset, trash_docs=True, normalize=True, lowercase=True, stopwords=True, contractions=True, vulgar_words=True, emails=True, punctuation=True, ngrams='uni', min_bigrams_count=50, bigrams_threshold=75, min_trigrams_count=100, trigrams_threshold=175, lemmatize=True, stem=False, trash_words=True, apostrophes=True, chars=True, empty_docs=True) → topics_and_summary.datasets.structured_dataset.StructuredDataset[source]¶

Creates a copy of the given dataset and returns the dataset copy with the specified preprocessing applied. The preprocessing options applied (including the ngrams_model_func if it’s the case) are stored in the preprocessing_options attribute of the returned dataset. The original dataset is not modified.

Parameters

  • min_bigrams_count – If ngrams is ‘bi’ or ‘tri’, this is the minimum number of occurrences of a bigram to be transformed as a bigram.

  • bigrams_threshold – If ngrams is ‘bi’ or ‘tri’, this is the threshold for creating a bigram.

  • min_trigrams_count – If ngrams is ‘tri’, this is the minimum number of occurrences of a trigram to be transformed as a trigram.

  • trigrams_threshold – If ngrams is ‘tri’, this is the threshold for creating a trigram.

  • dataset – Dataset to copy and apply preprocessing.

  • trash_docs – Remove specified docs. By default is True.

  • normalize – Normalize words. By default is True.

  • lowercase – Transform to lowercase. By default is True.

  • stopwords – Remove stopwords. By default is True.

  • contractions – Expand contractions. By default is True.

  • vulgar_words – Substitute vulgar words. By default is True.

  • emails – Remove emails. By default is True.

  • punctuation – Remove punctuation. By default is True.

  • ngrams – If ‘uni’ uses unigrams. If ‘bi’ create bigrams and returns bigram function. If ‘tri’ creates trigrams and returns trigram function. By default is ‘uni’.

  • lemmatize – Lemmatize words. By default is True.

  • stem – Stemm words. By default is False.

  • trash_words – Remove documents with any of the ‘trash words’. By default is True.

  • apostrophes – Remove apostrophes.

  • chars – Remove single chars. By default is True.

  • empty_docs – Remove empty docs. By default is True.

Returns

The dataset with the preprocessing applied.

Note that lemmatize and stem shouldn’t be both True, because only one of them will be applied.
